thread.title: Embattled President Trump invites phanatic Gene Huber on stage at Florida rally - Yahoo7
thread.title_full: Embattled President Trump invites phanatic Gene Huber on stage at Florida rally - Yahoo7

author: Agencies On February
title: Embattled President Trump invites phanatic Gene Huber on stage at Florida rally - Yahoo7
text:
Share Embattled President Trump invites phanatic Gene Huber on stage at Florida rally - Yahoo7 With his presidency in chaos and political adversaries baying for blood, a tie-less President Donald Trump took a different approach during his latest appearance - inviting and hugging an adoring fan onto centre stage. Close Man salutes cardboard cutout of President Trump everyday UP NEXT VIDEO Man salutes cardboard cutout of President Trump everyday. Source: CNN Man salutes cardboard cutout of President Trump everyday 
Unlike previous presidents, Trump chose not to focus on his administration's transition into power but rather aiming to reconnect with with his tribe of largely white, male middle-class voters. 
And he did just that - inviting the most loyal of followers, car salesman Gene Huber, to join him on stage. 
"Come on up here... I'm not not worried, I'm not worried about him," Trump said as the fanatic raced to the stage. Donald Trump could be seen stopping his secret service detail, telling them to let Gene Huber on the stage. Source: Twitter Follow Gene Huber on Twitter! Here's his account: @Squeakey6 pic.twitter.com/W0K7AKPHeS — Trump 2020 (@TrumpSource) February 19, 2017 
"When President Trump during the election promised all these things that he was gonna do for us, I knew he was gonna do this for us," Huber said on stage after giving the 45th POTUS a hug. 
Trump shook Huber's hand and said "A star is born" as Huber left the stage. 
Obsessed would be putting Mr Huber's feelings towards the President lightly. 
After the rally, he told CNN that he salutes a cardboard cutout of Trump every day. The Best Vistor I could ever have!President Trump came to Florida to see me! Wow, never will forget this!@realDonaldTrump @thebestcloser pic.twitter.com/galTF85biz — Gene Huber (@Squeakey6) January 9, 2017 Mr Huber shared a screenshot of a phone call that he claimed to be from Donald Trump. Source: Facebook 
"I love our president. He's coming out for us, we the people," Mr Huber added. 
He said he was first in line, arriving at 4:00 am to see his Republican political hero. 
Huber and many other Trump fans around him were dismissive when asked whether they were concerned that Trump, as the country's 45th president, was employing the same contentious style from his time on the campaign trail. 
"No jitters at all," Huber said. "This is a world leader now who's taking control." 
Not everyone was so convinced by Trump's sudden warmth. Gene Huber was staged. Def not a random. Here's his FB page: https://t.co/7GG6OGMiYG Posted from Trump Winery two days ago. pic.twitter.com/SqIQWTMFAz — JackiSchechner (@JackiSchechner) February 18, 2017 
Trump then proceeded to take aim at his favourite foil, the "dishonest" news media that he said has become "part of the corrupt system". 
The provocative real estate mogul-turned-leader of the free world reverted to doing what he does best on Saturday, campaigning. 
The rally locale had all the flair and anticipation of a campaign event from 2016: Thousands of supporters in line, women wearing red "Make America Great Again" hats, men in "Bikers for Trump" shirts, toddlers asleep on parents' shoulders, and plenty of Trump merchandise for sale. 
The event was designed to provide Trump an opportunity to bond with his base after a tumultuous start to his presidency. President Donald Trump and first lady Melania Trump arrive for the "Make America Great Again Rally" at Orlando-Melbourne International Airport. Source: AAP The Trump supporters were out in force for his Florida arrival. Source: AAP 
Florida has been good to the New York billionaire, and Trump was clearly relishing the chance to return to the stump here. 
"Big crowd expected!" he tweeted. 
The populous southeastern state backed Trump in November, helping him seal his shock victory over his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton. 
But the decision to hold the event appears to defy convention in Washington, coming as it does just one month into Trump's four-year term, when most new presidents are focused on finding their footing and getting their national security team and cabinet up to speed. Gene Huber, a man brought on stage by Trump, was first in line today,10 hrs ahead of time: "To be first at a #TrumpRally rally is an honor". pic.twitter.com/nN0uDp3uDB
